tickets.summary: Reading more than a byte at a time?
tickets.description: echoping performs one read\(\) system call per character. It would be probably faster \(benchmark it\) to collect several characters.

posts.text:
An experimental version implements buffered read.
You can get it with CVS, on the branch buffered-read-3-0-BETA
It improves performances for remote servers but degrades horribly for local servers. help welcome.
posts.author: bortz
posts.subject: #1 Reading more than a byte at a time?

posts.text:
- **assigned_to**: nobody --> bortz
- **status**: Error - status not found --> open-later
posts.author: bortz
posts.subject: #1 Reading more than a byte at a time?

posts.text: Stevens \(section 13.8 of Unix network programming, second edition\) suggests to solve this problem by using the libc, instead of system calls, and to do a fgets instead of read.
posts.author: bortz
posts.subject: #1 Reading more than a byte at a time?

posts.text: Fixed in the current CVS tree, with the use of fgets.
posts.author: bortz
posts.subject: #1 Reading more than a byte at a time?

posts.text:
Here are the results for the fgets version, on a Linux/glibc machine:

HTTP, local
fgets 0.005 s
read 0.025 s

echo, local
fgets 0.002 s
read 0.003 s
With the default size, the fgets version gets quickly much faster when the size increases.

HTTP ethernet
fgets 0.010
read 0.023

echo ethernet
fget 0.005
read 0.006
With larger sizes:
fgets 0.023
read 0.058

HTTP remote
no difference

echo disant
no difference
posts.author: bortz
posts.subject: #1 Reading more than a byte at a time?

posts.text: Properly fixed in 4.0.0

posts.subject: #1 Reading more than a byte at a time?

tickets.summary: echoping does not work with chunked encoding
tickets.description:
If an HTTP/1.1 server uses chunked encoding to send the reply, 
echoping waits relatively long for the connection to close. The 
desirable behavior would be that echoping interpret the chunked 
encoding \(this shouldn't be too hard, read the line containing the hex 
encoded size of the next chunk, read the chunk, and repeat until the 
chunk size is 0, which indicates the end of the response\), so that
it can accurately measure the time it takes the server to send the 
response, not the timeout to connection close.

Temporary workaround for me: replace version string 1.1 by 1.0, so 
the server is no longer tempted to use chunked encoding.

posts.text:
- **assigned_to**: nobody --> bortz
- **status**: open --> open-later
posts.author: bortz
posts.subject: #29 echoping does not work with chunked encoding

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=25865
Originator: NO

Anyone knows a HTTP server which uses chunked encoding? It would be easier to test the patch.

I do not find where I enable it in Apache configuration. It seems it is automatic if Apache does not know the content length. http://httpd.apache.org/docs/2.2/mod/core.html\#keepalive

RFC 2616, section 3.6.1 and 19.4.6, which includes pseudo-code

posts.subject: #29 echoping does not work with chunked encoding

tickets.summary: No interleaving of writes and reads
tickets.description:
Since echoping writes everything to the server, then begins to read
the reply, some echo servers will timeout if you send very long
messages, because they expect you to start to read right now.

Of course, it does not apply to half-duplex protocols like HTTP or SMTP.

@@ -11,9 +11,7 @@
\#define DEFLINE 256
\#define MAXLINE 65535
\#define UDPMAX 65535
-\#ifdef HTTP
\#define MAXTOREAD 150000
-\#endif
\#ifdef SMTP
\#define MAXSMTP 1024
\#define MAXSMTPLINES 30

tickets.summary: RedHat 7 is broken and it breaks echoping
tickets.description:
Some versions of RedHat, like 7.3, ships with a completely broken C compiler \(which presents itself as 
gcc 2.96, which was never released by the gcc team\). It tells a lot about RedHat quality insurance but 
the important point is that it breaks echoping: some displayed times are negative. There is no other 
solution than reformatting your hard drive and installing a proper operating system.

http://gcc.gnu.org/gcc-2.96.html

tickets.summary: Concatenation of option name with option value
tickets.description:
Since the switch to the popt library in echoping 6, there \*must\* be a space between the option name and the option value. So:

echoping -h/ localhost

is no longer accepted, it has to be:

echoping -h / localhost

Two problems:

\* some scripts may use the old syntax \(it is the case with Smokeping's EchoPingHttp\) so a way to get the old behavior would be nice

\* "man" displays the usage as: -hurl-or-path despite the fact there \*is\* a space in the nroff source:
.RI \[-h url-or-path\]

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=25865
Originator: YES

Do note that Smokeping >= 2.1.0 fixed the problem in its probes so there is no emergency.
posts.author: bortz
posts.subject: #42 Concatenation of option name with option value

tickets.summary: http check appends :80 to HTTP Host header
tickets.description:
When using echoping from smokeping, echoping will be called with:
\# echoping -H www.vg.no --http /  www.vg.no

echoping creates a HTTP request with a host header of: "Host: www.vg.no:80".

This is valid according to 
http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec14.html
but it seems to be a bit odd. 

The site in question returns a 302 Moved for this request, which faults the service check.

Suggested fix:
\* only append port number to Host header if the port is different from 80.

posts.text: Minor patch that fixes this issue.

posts.text: I've made a small patch that fixes this, and attached it below.

tickets.summary: Licence should change because of OpenSSL
tickets.description:
Apparently, OpenSSL is not compatible with the GPL :-\( and therefore a waiver should be granted:

Subject: Re: openssl issue
From: Matthew Palmer &lt;mjp16@ieee.uow.edu.au&gt;
To: Pasi Savilaakso &lt;pasi.savilaakso@pp.inet.fi&gt;
Cc: debian-legal@lists.debian.org
Date: Wed, 30 Apr 2003 16:37:05 +1000 \(EST\)
On Wed, 30 Apr 2003, Pasi Savilaakso wrote:

&gt;       I have a question concerning about openssl issue. I am packaging one 
\[...\]
&gt; Question is simple. How must the software be licenced or changed, if any,
&gt; so that it can be accepted to debian? would licencing it under LGPL help?
&gt; I would like to keep ssl/compatible functionality in the program.

I take it you're referring to the general inability to redistribute GPL'd
applications which link to OpenSSL.

Basically, all copyright holders of the GPL'd work need to waive the
restriction against linking to non-GPL'd libraries, specifically the
OpenSSL.  I believe something similar to the licence exemption quoted in
http://lists.debian.org/debian-legal/2002/debian-legal-200207/msg00454.html
would be suitable, replacing the names as appropriate.

The other alternative would be to replace the need for OpenSSL with a need
for GNUTLS, which is of course licenced in a GPL-compatible manner.

&gt; I am seeking answer to just this particular question, but if you want you can 
&gt; also email me about technical issues too privately, since it is offtopic. 
Tech issues would be quite appropriate for debian-devel or debian-mentors...

&gt; I promised to upstream author that I will tell him options what he can do to 
&gt; make his work distributable with debian. 

I'm pretty sure that putting the exemption in the message referenced above
would do the job pretty well.

&gt; Please CC me, I am not subscriber of the list. 

Done.


\-- 
\-----------------------------------------------------------------------
\#include &lt;disclaimer.h&gt;
Matthew Palmer, Geek In Residence
http://ieee.uow.edu.au/~mjp16

tickets.summary: LDAP plugin may retrieve too many objects and exceed max siz
tickets.description:
\[Reported by Joerg Roth\]

By default, echoping LDAP plugin does a request of \(objectclass=\*\) which retrieve every object at the mentioned base. This may be too much:

% echoping -t 5 -m ldap -n 20 directory.uzh.ch -r \\\(objectclass=\*\\\) -b ou=Addressbook,dc=uzh,dc=ch
Cannot connect to directory.uzh.ch \(no LDAP server or wrong base, probably\):
Size limit exceeded

Using -r to change this default value may not be sufficient since ldap\_search\_s first call is always done with a \(objectclass=\*\), just to test the server.

A better solution may be \(objectclass=dummy\) to test the server but without retrieving everything.

posts.text:
Logged In: YES

tickets.summary: echoping 5.0.1 changes for Mac OS X
tickets.description:
To compile and run on powerpc-apple-darwin6.6 \(Mac OS X
10.2.6\), I had to make the following two changes.  The
change to the setsockopt call was required to get
echoping.c to compile.  The setsockopt man page for Mac
OS gives a prototype of

int
setsockopt\(int s, int level, int optname, const
void \*optval,
int optlen\);

The compiler error was:

echoping.c:672: \`socklen\_t' undeclared \(first use in
this function\)
echoping.c:672: \(Each undeclared identifier is
reported only once
echoping.c:672: for each function it appears in.\)
echoping.c:672: parse error before &quot;sizeof&quot;

The second change was to the case of the HTTP service
name in the call to getaddrinfo. With it in upper case,
echoping produced the error:

Fire$ ./echoping -h http://www.apple.com/ www.apple.com
getaddrinfo error for host: www.apple.com No address
associated with nodename

I have not tested using echoping with the other
services, so the other service names might need to be
lowercased too.




diff -u -r echoping-5.0.1.orig/echoping.c
echoping-5.0.1/echoping.c
\--- echoping-5.0.1.orig/echoping.c      2002-11-04
07:37:34.000000000 -0800
+++ echoping-5.0.1/echoping.c   2003-06-24
22:31:09.000000000 -0700
@@ -669,7 +669,7 @@
\}
if \(setsockopt \(sockfd,
SOL\_IP,
\-                         IP\_TOS, \(void \*\) &amp;tos,
\(socklen\_t\) sizeof \(tos\)\)\)
\+                         IP\_TOS, \(void \*\) &amp;tos,
\(unsigned int\) sizeof \(tos\)\)\)
\{
err\_sys \(&quot;Failed setting IP type of
service octet&quot;\);
\}
diff -u -r echoping-5.0.1.orig/echoping.h
echoping-5.0.1/echoping.h
\--- echoping-5.0.1.orig/echoping.h      2002-10-11
05:12:53.000000000 -0700
+++ echoping-5.0.1/echoping.h   2003-06-25
00:35:05.000000000 -0700
@@ -114,7 +114,7 @@
\#define        ECHO\_TCP\_PORT   &quot;echo&quot;
\#define        DISCARD\_TCP\_PORT        &quot;discard&quot;
\#define        CHARACTER\_GENERATOR\_TCP\_PORT    &quot;chargen&quot;
-\#define DEFAULT\_HTTP\_TCP\_PORT &quot;HTTP&quot;
+\#define DEFAULT\_HTTP\_TCP\_PORT &quot;http&quot;
\#define DEFAULT\_HTTPS\_TCP\_PORT &quot;HTTPS&quot;
\#define DEFAULT\_ICP\_UDP\_PORT &quot;ICP&quot;

tickets.summary: Removes T/TCP support (security)
tickets.description:
T/TCP \(RFC 1644\) was a fine idea but it never really
started \(only FreeBSD implemented it and dropped it
with version 6.0-RELEASE\). 

It seems to have security problems. For instance,   
the IETF internet-draft draft-ietf-tcpm-tcp-roadmap-05
says:

The inventors of TCP believed that cached connection
state could
have been used to eliminate TCP's 3-way
handshake, to support two-
packet request/response exchanges.  RFCs 1379
\[RFC1379\] and 1644
\[RFC1644\] show that this is far from simple. 
Furthermore, T/TCP
floundered on the ease of denial-of-service
attacks that can
result.  One idea pioneered by T/TCP lives on in
RFC 2140, in the
sharing of state across connections.

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=25865
Originator: YES

The draft has been published as RFC 4614

RFC 1644 E "T/TCP -- TCP Extensions for Transactions Functional
Specification" \(July 1994\): found defective

The inventors of TCP believed that cached connection state could
have been used to eliminate TCP's 3-way handshake, to support
two-packet request/response exchanges.  RFCs 1379 \[RFC1379\] and
1644 \[RFC1644\] show that this is far from simple.  Furthermore,
T/TCP floundered on the ease of denial-of-service attacks that can
result.  One idea pioneered by T/TCP lives on in RFC 2140, in the
sharing of state across connections.

tickets.summary: usleep() call is wrong in most cases
tickets.description:
SUSv3 description for usleep\(\) states:

"The useconds argument shall be less than one million."

echoping.c, however, uses usleep\(wait \* 1000000\), which
has the effect on some OSes \(including NetBSD\) of not
sleeping at all for wait >= 1.0.  This patch makes it DTRT:

diff -u echoping.c.orig echoping.c
\--- echoping.c.orig     2006-04-20 15:09:49.000000000 -0700
+++ echoping.c  2006-04-20 15:20:24.000000000 -0700
@@ -655,7 +655,13 @@
if \(i > 1\)
\{
\#ifdef HAVE\_USLEEP
\-         usleep \(wait \* 1000000\);
\+         /\*
\+          \* SUSv3 states that the argument to usleep\(\)
shall be less
\+          \* than 1000000, so split into two calls if
necessary.
\+          \*/ 
\+         if \(wait >= 1\)
\+               sleep \(wait\);
\+         usleep \(\(wait - \(unsigned int\)wait\) \* 1000000\);
\#else
sleep \(wait\);
\#endif



\(please forgive whitespace issues with this cut-and-paste\)

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=25865

Thanks for the report, I knew I was right to maintain a
NetBSD machine, I'll test your patch.
posts.author: bortz
posts.subject: #32 usleep() call is wrong in most cases

posts.text: - **assigned_to**: nobody --> bortz

tickets.summary: Obsolete terminology for TOS
tickets.description:
echoping, drawing from the Posix API, uses obsolete terminology for things like the TOS \(options -p and -P\). Defined by RFC 791, termes like "priority" and "type of service" have been obsoleted by the Diffserv stuff \(RFC 2474 and friends\).

Posix still uses the old names and values and so does the man pages \(for intance ip\(7\) on Linux\) One can wonder wether echoping should align on Posix or on the RFC.

tickets.summary: Very wrong loss value because out of order packects
tickets.description:
I'm trying to use echoping udp \(echo\) with a fast sending rate on a WAN link.


I'm using a 100 ms rate :

echoping -w 0.1 -u -n 20 -t 1 host


As soon as an echo packet come back out of order, echoping issue an ICMP destination port unreachable and refuse it.


This give very unaccurate loss results. In my case about ten times the real amount of loss.

It seems as well that echoping does not always change the udp source port number for each ping, so that it can make packet confusions \(the Echo data is the same for all the ping session\).


Could someone write a patch to correct this problem ?



Thanks for your listening.

tickets.summary: Minor fix on manpage.
tickets.description:
Fix for echoping.1.in:161

Manual page seems to contain a hyphen where a minus sign was intended. '-' chars are interpreted as hyphens \(U+2010\) by groff, not as minus signs \(U+002D\). Since options to programs use minus signs \(U+002D\), this means for example in UTF-8 locales that you cannot cut&paste options, nor search for them easily.

tickets.summary: echoping: Fails to build against gnutls26 >= 2.7.x
tickets.description:
Hi bortz,

I'm echoping's Debian package maintainer. Do you remember me?

I've got this bug report under Debian \[0\] and I was wondering if you can provide a solution for it directly in echoping source to be buildable when gnutls26 reaches 2.7.x version.

\[0\] http://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=529820

Thanks in advance.

posts.text:
This should work:

\----------------------------
\--- echoping-6.0.2.orig/configure.ac
+++ echoping-6.0.2/configure.ac
@@ -92,14 +93,21 @@
AC\_ARG\_WITH\(gnutls,
\[  --with-gnutls\[=DIR\]   SSL/TLS crypt support \(needs GNU TLS\), the argument DIR should not be necessary\],dnl
\[if test "$withval" \!= "no"; then
\-   AC\_DEFINE\(GNUTLS,,\[Crypto \(TLS\) support\]\)
\-   GNUTLS=1
\-   CPPFLAGS="$\{CPPFLAGS\} \`libgnutls-config --cflags\`"
\-   LDFLAGS="$\{LDFLAGS\} \`libgnutls-config --libs\`"
\-   if test "$withval" \!= "yes"; then
\-	GNUTLSROOT=$withval
\-	LDFLAGS="$\{LDFLAGS\} -L$GNUTLSROOT/lib"
\-        CPPFLAGS="$\{CPPFLAGS\} -I$GNUTLSROOT/include"  
\+   if test "$withval" = "yes"; then
\+     PKG\_CHECK\_MODULES\(\[LIBGNUTLS\], \[gnutls >= 1.0.0\],
\+       \[
\+       echo "GnuTLS found"
\+       AC\_DEFINE\(GNUTLS,,\[Crypto \(TLS\) support\]\)
\+       GNUTLS=1
\+       CFLAGS="$CFLAGS $LIBGNUTLS\_CFLAGS"
\+       LIBS="$LIBS $LIBGNUTLS\_LIBS"
\+       \],\)
\+   else
\+     AC\_DEFINE\(GNUTLS,,\[Crypto \(TLS\) support\]\)
\+     GNUTLS=1
\+     GNUTLSROOT=$withval
\+     LDFLAGS="$\{LDFLAGS\} -L$GNUTLSROOT/lib -lgnutls"
\+     CPPFLAGS="$\{CPPFLAGS\} -I$GNUTLSROOT/include"  
fi
fi\],
dnl Default: disable it 
\----------------------------

The whole thing can be simplified  lot by drpping the else clause, obviously.

On a sidenote I needed to move "AC\_INIT\(echoping, 6.0.2, bortz@users.sourceforge.net\)" from configure-common.ac to all the separate configure.ac files to be able regenerate the other auto\* files. autoreconf and libtoolize both check for this line in configure.ac and do nothing if it cannot be found. \(If I do not do this the new libtool.m4 and old ltmain.sh are combined to a non-working libtool script, exactly as in http.//bugs.debian.org/529701\)

tickets.summary: echoping DNS plugin ignores the hostname argument
tickets.description:
Hi Stephane,

Hereby I'm forwarding a bugs reported on echoping Debian package...

\--- \[ ORIGINAL BUG REPORT \] ---

Whatever host argument is supplied to echoping's DNS plugin, it ignores
it, and just uses the resolver as listed in /etc/resolv.conf etc.
instead.

Still present in upstream DNS.  This behaviour should at least be
clearly documented.

http://echoping.svn.sourceforge.net/viewvc/echoping/trunk/SRC/plugins/dns/dns.c?view=markup

Thanks...

\--- \[ ORIGINAL BUG REPORT \] ---


I'll wait for your opinion before taking any step on this issue.

Cheers.

\[0\] http://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=588261

tickets.summary: Should not translate IDN names to Unicode blindly
tickets.description:
Today, echoping, if compiled with IDN support, translates Unicode names to ACE \(xn--something\) systematically, with idna\_to\_ascii\_8z, before calling getaddrinfo. According to the future IAB RFC \(currently Internet-Draft draft-iab-idn-encoding\), this is a bad idea since resolution can be done by other protocols than the DNS.

No obvious solution to this problem: Posix does not let an ordinary application know if getaddrinfo will use DNS, hosts file, LDAP, etc.

posts.text: The standard about IDN handling has now been published as RFC 6055.
posts.author: bortz
posts.subject: #54 Should not translate IDN names to Unicode blindly

tickets.description:
The following bug has been reported on Debian Bug Tracking System and patches has been provided.

http://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=606808

\--- \[ Reported bug \] ---
Package: echoping
Version: 6.0.2-3
Severity: grave
Tags: security patch
Justification: user security hole

I use Smokeping to monitor a number of external hosts. echoping is
called by EchoPingHttps Smokeping probe, and it crashes several times a
week, resulting in syslog error like: 

Dec 11 00:13:27 bor kernel: \[49668.766339\] echoping\[17510\]: segfault at 767c858e ip 0804db39 sp bfea8710 error 4 in echoping\[8048000+9000\]

Hopefully, I found the source of this crash. I'm now running the patched
echoping binary to verify the fix, which is provided below. \(Strictly
speaking, only the last change is required, but the former two improve
safety without causing any harm.\)
\--- \[ Reported bug \] ---


The last provided patch is attached.
I'll wait for your advise in order to apply it.

Regards,

posts.text:
- **milestone**:  --> Normal
- **assigned_to**: nobody --> bortz
- **status**: open --> open-fixed
posts.author: bortz
posts.subject: #55 echoping crashes sometimes when used against HTTPS hosts

posts.text:
Posting the answer here as well:
"My concern is the third gnutls\_record\_recv\(\) call. 'maxlen' argument
of TLS\_readline\(\) was passed to the call as is, and TLS\_readline\(\)
callers \*always pass the full size\* of TLS\_buffer\[\] as 'maxlen', but
pointer passed to the gnutls\_record\_recv\(\) is \(TLS\_buffer + some
offset\). So, in theory, remote side could send specifically prepared
data which could overwrite up to MAXTOREAD bytes past the buffer. As
I'm not a security expert, I can't say for sure if it is really
exploitable or not, but it does not look good at all."

tickets.summary: Uses deprecated _set_priority GnuTLS functions
tickets.description:
For your reference this bug is based on http://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=624049

echoping is using some functions which are marked deprecated in
newer versions of GnuTLS \(>=2.12.x\). \(They are not yet removed, though.\)
These functions will be removed in future releases.

Excerpt from buildlog:
====================================================
echoping.c:1024:6: warning: 'gnutls\_certificate\_type\_set\_priority' is deprecated \(declared at /usr/include/gnutls/compat.h:347\)
====================================================

The gnutls\_\*\_set\_priority family of functions has been marked deprecated
in 2.12.x. These functions have been superceded by 
gnutls\_priority\_set\_direct\(\). The replacement function was added in gnutls
stable release 2.2.0 \(released 2007-12-14\).

Regards,

- **milestone**:  --> Normal

- **assigned_to**: nobody --> bortz
- **status**: open --> open-accepted

posts.subject: #56 Uses deprecated _set_priority GnuTLS functions
